title: Titus Andronicus from Mr. William Shakespeares comedies, histories, & tragedies. Published according to the true originall copies.

characters.name: Titus Andronicus, a noble Roman, general against the Goths.
Aaron, a Moor, beloved by Tamora
Bassianus, brother to Saturninus; in love with Lavinia
Saturninus, son to the late Emperor of Rome, and afterwards declared Emperor
Marcus Andronicus, tribune of the people, and brother to Titus
Publius, son to Marcus the Tribune

lines.speaker: Saturninus.
lines.text: Noble Patricians, Patrons of my right,

lines.speaker: Saturninus.
lines.text: Defend the iustice of my Cause with Armes.

lines.speaker: Saturninus.
lines.text: And Countrey‑men, my louing Followers,

lines.speaker: Saturninus.
lines.text: Pleade my Successiue Title with your Swords.

lines.speaker: Saturninus.
lines.text: I was the first borne Sonne, that was the last

lines.speaker: Saturninus.
lines.text: That wore the Imperiall Diadem of Rome:

lines.speaker: Saturninus.
lines.text: Then let my Fathers Honours liue in me,

lines.speaker: Saturninus.
lines.text: Nor wrong mine Age with this indignitie.

lines.speaker: Bassianus.
lines.text: Romaines, Friends, Followers,

lines.speaker: Bassianus.
lines.text: Fauourers of my Right:

lines.speaker: Bassianus.
lines.text: If euer {% italic: Bassianus, Cæsars %} Sonne,

lines.speaker: Bassianus.
lines.text: Were gracious in the eyes of Royall Rome,

lines.speaker: Bassianus.
lines.text: Keepe then this passage to the Capitoll:

lines.speaker: Bassianus.
lines.text: And suffer not Dishonour to approach

lines.speaker: Bassianus.
lines.text: Th' Imperiall Seate to Vertue: consecrate

lines.speaker: Bassianus.
lines.text: To Iustice, Continence, and Nobility:

lines.speaker: Bassianus.
lines.text: But let Desert in pure Election shine;

lines.speaker: Bassianus.
lines.text: And Romanes, fight for Freedome in your Choice.

lines.speaker: Saturnine.
lines.text: How fayre the Tribune speakes,

lines.speaker: Saturnine.
lines.text: To calme my thoughts.

lines.speaker: Bassia.
lines.text: {% italic: Marcus Andronicus %}, so I do affie

lines.speaker: Bassia.
lines.text: In thy vprightnesse and Integrity:

lines.speaker: Bassia.
lines.text: And so I Loue and Honor thee, and thine,

lines.speaker: Bassia.
lines.text: Thy Noble Brother {% italic: Titus %}, and his Sonnes,

lines.speaker: Bassia.
lines.text: And Her (to whom my thoughts are humbled all)

lines.speaker: Bassia.
lines.text: Gracious {% italic: Lauinia %}, Romes rich Ornament,

lines.speaker: Bassia.
lines.text: That I will heere dismisse my louing Friends:

lines.speaker: Bassia.
lines.text: And to my Fortunes, and the Peoples Fauour,

lines.speaker: Bassia.
lines.text: Commit my Cause in ballance to be weigh'd.

lines.speaker: Saturnine.
lines.text: Friends, that haue beene

lines.speaker: Saturnine.
lines.text: Thus forward in my Right,

lines.speaker: Saturnine.
lines.text: I thanke you all, and heere Dismisse you all,

lines.speaker: Saturnine.
lines.text: And to the Loue and Fauour of my Countrey,

lines.speaker: Saturnine.
lines.text: Commit my Selfe, my Person, and the Cause:

lines.speaker: Saturnine.
lines.text: Rome, be as iust and gracious vnto me,

lines.speaker: Saturnine.
lines.text: As I am confident and kinde to thee.

lines.speaker: Saturnine.
lines.text: Open the Gates, and let me in.

lines.speaker: Bassia.
lines.text: Tribunes, and me, a poore Competitor.

lines.speaker: Cap.
lines.text: Romanes make way: the good {% italic: Andronicus %},

lines.speaker: Cap.
lines.text: Patron of Vertue, Romes best Champion,

lines.speaker: Cap.
lines.text: Successefull in the Battailes that he fights,

lines.speaker: Cap.
lines.text: With Honour and with Fortune is return'd,

lines.speaker: Cap.
lines.text: From whence he circumscribed with his Sword,

lines.speaker: Cap.
lines.text: And brought to yoke the Enemies of Rome.

lines.speaker: Andronicus.
lines.text: Haile Rome:

lines.speaker: Andronicus.
lines.text: Victorious in thy Mourning Weedes: The large tear does not appear to have contained any text at this point.

lines.speaker: Andronicus.
lines.text: The letter L has slipped up the page, above the rest of the line. Loe as the Barke that hath discharg'd his fraught,

lines.speaker: Andronicus.
lines.text: Returnes with precious lading to the Bay,

lines.speaker: Andronicus.
lines.text: From whence at first she weigh'd her Anchorage:

lines.speaker: Andronicus.
lines.text: Commeth {% italic: Andronicus %} bound with Lawrell bowes,

lines.speaker: Andronicus.
lines.text: To resalute his Country with his teares,

lines.speaker: Andronicus.
lines.text: Teares of true ioy for his returne to Rome,

lines.speaker: Andronicus.
lines.text: Thou great defender of this Capitoll,

lines.speaker: Andronicus.
lines.text: Stand gracious to the Rites that we intend.

lines.speaker: Andronicus.
lines.text: Romaines, of fiue and twenty Valiant Sonnes,

lines.speaker: Andronicus.
lines.text: Halfe of the number that King {% italic: Priam %} had,

lines.speaker: Andronicus.
lines.text: Behold the poore remaines aliue and dead!

lines.speaker: Andronicus.
lines.text: These that Suruiue, let Rome reward with Loue:

lines.speaker: Andronicus.
lines.text: These that I bring vnto their latest home,

lines.speaker: Andronicus.
lines.text: With buriall amongst their Auncestors.

lines.speaker: Andronicus.
lines.text: Heere Gothes haue giuen me leaue to sheath my Sword:

lines.speaker: Andronicus.
lines.text: {% italic: Titus %} vnkinde, and carelesse of thine owne,

lines.speaker: Andronicus.
lines.text: Why suffer'st thou thy Sonnes vnburied yet,

lines.speaker: Andronicus.
lines.text: To houer on the dreadfull shore of Stix?

lines.speaker: Andronicus.
lines.text: Make way to lay them by their Bretheren.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Giue vs the proudest prisoner of the Gothes,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: That we may hew his limbes, and on a pile

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: {% italic: Ad manus fratrum %}, sacrifice his flesh:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Before this earthly prison of their bones,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: That so the shadowes be not vnappeas'd,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Nor we disturb'd with prodigies on earth.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: I giue him you, the Noblest that Suruiues,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: The eldest Son of this distressed Queene.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Stay Romaine Bretheren, gracious Conqueror,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Victorious {% italic: Titus %}, rue the teares I shed,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: A Mothers teares in passion for her sonne:

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: And if thy Sonnes were euer deere to thee,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Oh thinke my sonnes to be as deere to mee.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Sufficeth not, that we are brought to Rome

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: To beautifie thy Triumphs, and returne

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Captiue to thee, and to thy Romaine yoake,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: But must my Sonnes be slaughtred in the streetes,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: For Valiant doings in their Countries cause?

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: O! If to fight for King and Common‑weale,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Were piety in thine, it is in these:

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: {% italic: Andronicus %}, staine not thy Tombe with blood.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Wilt thou draw neere the nature of the Gods?

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Draw neere them then in being mercifull.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Sweet mercy is Nobilities true badge,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Thrice Noble {% italic: Titus %}, spare my first borne sonne.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Patient your selfe Madam, and pardon me.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: These are the Brethren, whom you Gothes beheld

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Aliue and dead, and for their Bretheren slaine,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Religiously they aske a sacrifice:

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: To this your sonne is markt, and die he must,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: T' appease their groaning shadowes that are gone.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Away with him, and make a fire straight,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: And with our Swords vpon a pile of wood,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Let's hew his limbes till they be cleane consum'd.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: See Lord and Father, how we haue perform'd

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Our Romaine rightes, {% italic: Alarbus %} limbs are lopt,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: And intrals feede the sacrifising fire,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Whole smoke like incense doth perfume the skie.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Remaineth nought but to interre our Brethren,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: And with low'd Larums welcome them to Rome.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Let it be so, and let {% italic: Andronicus %}

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Make this his latest farewell to their soules.

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: In peace and Honour, liue Lord {% italic: Titus %} long,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: My Noble Lord and Father, liue in Fame:

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Loe at this Tombe my tributarie teares,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: I render for my Bretherens Obsequies:

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: And at thy feete I kneele, with teares of ioy

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Shed on the earth for thy returne to Rome.

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: O blesse me heere with thy victorious hand,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Whose Fortune Romes best Citizens applau'd.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Kind Rome,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: That hast thus louingly reseru'd

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: The Cordiall of mine age to glad my hart,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: {% italic: Lauinia %} liue, out‑liue thy Fathers dayes:

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: And Fames eternall date for vertues praise.

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: Long liue Lord {% italic: Titus %}, my beloued brother,

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: Gracious Triumpher in the eyes of Rome.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Thankes Gentle Tribune,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Noble brother {% italic: Marcus %}.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And welcome Nephews from succesfull wars,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: You that suruiue and you that sleepe in Fame:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Faire Lords your Fortunes are all alike in all,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: That in your Countries seruice drew your Swords.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: But safer Triumph is this Funerall Pompe,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: That hath aspir'd to {% italic: Solons %} Happines,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And Triumphs ouer chaunce in honours bed.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: {% italic: Titus Andronicus %}, the people of Rome,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Whose friend in iustice thou hast euer bene,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Send thee by me their Tribune and their trust,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: This Palliament of white and spotlesse Hue,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And name thee in Election for the Empire,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: With these our late deceased Emperours Sonnes:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Be {% italic: Candidatus %} then, and put it on,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And helpe to set a head on headlesse Rome.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: A better head her Glorious body fits,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Then his that shakes for age and feeblenesse:

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: What should I d'on this Robe and trouble you,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Be chosen with proclamations to day,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: To morrow yeeld vp rule, resigne my life,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And set abroad new businesse for you all.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Rome I haue bene thy Souldier forty yeares,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And led my Countries strength successefully,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And buried one and twenty Valiant Sonnes,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Knighted in Field, slaine manfully in Armes,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: In right and Seruice of their Noble Countrie:

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Giue me a staffe of Honour for mine age,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: But not a Scepter to controule the world,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Vpright he held it Lords, that held it last

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: {% italic: Titus %}, thou shalt obtaine and aske the Emperie.

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: Proud and ambitious Tribune can'st thou tell?

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: Patience Prince {% italic: Saturninus %}.

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: Romaines do me right.

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: Patricians draw your Swords, and sheath them not

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: Till {% italic: Saturninus %} be Romes Emperour:

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: {% italic: Andronicus %} would thou wert shipt to hell,

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: Rather then rob me of the peoples harts.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Proud {% italic: Saturnine %}, interrupter of the good

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: That Noble minded Titus meanes to thee.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Content thee Prince, I will restore to thee

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: The peoples harts, and weane them from themselues.

lines.speaker: Bass.
lines.text: {% italic: Andronicus %}, I do not flatter thee

lines.speaker: Bass.
lines.text: But Honour thee, and will doe till I die:

lines.speaker: Bass.
lines.text: My Faction if thou strengthen with thy Friend?

lines.speaker: Bass.
lines.text: I will most thankefull be, and thankes to men

lines.speaker: Bass.
lines.text: Of Noble mindes, is Honourable Meede.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: People of Rome, and Noble Tribunes heere,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: I aske your voyces and your Suffrages,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Will you bestow them friendly on {% italic: Andronicus %}?

lines.speaker: Tribunes.
lines.text: To gratifie the good {% italic: Andronicus %},

lines.speaker: Tribunes.
lines.text: And Gratulate his safe returne to Rome,

lines.speaker: Tribunes.
lines.text: The people will accept whom he admits.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Tribunes I thanke you, and this sure I make,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: That you Create your Emperours eldest sonne,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Lord {% italic: Saturnine %}, whose Vertues will I hope,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Reflect on Rome as Tytans Rayes on earth,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And ripen Iustice in this Common‑weale:

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Then if you will elect by my aduise,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Crowne him, and say: Long liue our Emperour.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: {% italic: An %}. With Voyces and applause of euery sort,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Patricians and Plebeans we Create

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Lord {% italic: Saturninus %} Romes Great Emperour.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And say, {% italic: Long liue our Emperour Saturnine %}.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: {% italic: A long Flourish till they come downe %}.

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: {% italic: Titus Andronicus %}, for thy Fauours done,

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: To vs in our Election this day,

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: I giue thee thankes in part of thy Deserts,

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: And will with Deeds requite thy gentlenesse:

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: And for an Onset {% italic: Titus %} to aduance

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Thy Name, and Honorable Familie,

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: {% italic: Lauinia %} will I make my Empresse,

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Romes Royall Mistris, Mistris of my hart

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: And in the Sacred {% italic: Pathan %} her espouse:

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Tell me {% italic: Andronicus %} doth this motion please thee?

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: It doth my worthy Lord, and in this match,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: I hold me Highly Honoured of your Grace,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And heere in sight of Rome, to {% italic: Saturnine %},

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: King and Commander of our Common‑weale,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: The Wide‑worlds Emperour, do I Consecrate,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: My Sword, my Chariot, and my Prisoners,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Presents well Worthy Romes Imperiall Lord:

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Receiue them then, the Tribute that I owe,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Mine Honours Ensignes humbled at my feete.

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Thankes Noble {% italic: Titus %}, Father of my life,

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: How proud I am of thee, and of thy gifts

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Rome shall record, and when I do forget

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: The least of these vnspeakable Deserts,

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Romans forget your Fealtie to me.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Now Madam are your prisoner to an Emperour,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: To him that for you Honour and your State,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Will vse you Nobly and your followers.

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: A goodly Lady, trust me of the Hue

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: That I would choose, were I to choose a new:

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Cleere vp Faire Queene that cloudy countenance,

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Though chance of warre

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Hath wrought this change of cheere,

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Thou com'st not to be made a scorne in Rome:

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Princely shall be thy vsage euery way.

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Rest on my word, and let not discontent

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Daunt all your hopes: Madam he comforts you,

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Can make your Greater then the Queene of Gothes?

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: {% italic: Lauinia %} you are not displeas'd with this?

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: Not I my Lord, sith true Nobilitie,

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: Warrants these words in Princely curtesie.

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: Thankes sweete {% italic: Lauinia %}, Romans let vs goe:

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: Ransomlesse heere we set our Prisoners free,

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: Proclaime our Honors Lords with Trumpe and Drum.

lines.speaker: Bass.
lines.text: Lord {% italic: Titus %} by your leaue, this Maid is mine.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: How sir? Are you in earnest then my Lord?

lines.speaker: Bass.
lines.text: I Noble {% italic: Titus %}, and resolu'd withall,

lines.speaker: Bass.
lines.text: To doe my selfe this reason, and this right.

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: {% italic: Suum cuiquam %}, is our Romane Iustice,

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: This Prince in Iustice ceazeth but his owne.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: And that he will and shall, if {% italic: Lucius %} liue.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Traytors auant, where is the Emperours Guarde?

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Treason my Lord, {% italic: Lauinia %} is surpris'd.

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: Surpris'd, by whom?

lines.speaker: Bass.
lines.text: By him that iustly may

lines.speaker: Bass.
lines.text: Beare his Betroth'd, from all the world away.

lines.speaker: Muti.
lines.text: Brothers helpe to conuey her hence away,

lines.speaker: Muti.
lines.text: And with my Sword Ile keepe this doore safe.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Follow my Lord, and Ile soone bring her backe.

lines.speaker: Mut.
lines.text: My Lord you passe not heere.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: What villaine Boy, bar'st me my way in Rome?

lines.speaker: Mut.
lines.text: Helpe {% italic: Lucius %} helpe.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: My Lord you are vniust, and more then so,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: In wrongfull quarrell, you haue slaine your son.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Nor thou, nor he are any sonnes of mine,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: My sonnes would neuer so dishonour me.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Traytor restore {% italic: Lauinia %} to the Emperour.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Dead if you will, but not to be his wife,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: That is anothers lawfull promist Loue.

lines.speaker: Empe.
lines.text: No {% italic: Titus %}, no, the Emperour needs her not,

lines.speaker: Empe.
lines.text: Nor her, nor thee, nor any of thy stocke:

lines.speaker: Empe.
lines.text: Ile trust by Leisure him that mocks me once.

lines.speaker: Empe.
lines.text: Thee neuer: nor thy Trayterous haughty sonnes,

lines.speaker: Empe.
lines.text: Confederates all, thus to dishonour me.

lines.speaker: Empe.
lines.text: Was none in Rome to make a stale

lines.speaker: Empe.
lines.text: But {% italic: Saturnine %}? Full well {% italic: Andronicus %}

lines.speaker: Empe.
lines.text: Agree these Deeds, with that proud bragge of thine,

lines.speaker: Empe.
lines.text: That said'st, I beg'd the Empire at thy hands.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: O monstrous, what reproachfull words are these?

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: But goe thy wayes, goe giue that changing peece,

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: To him that flourisht for her with his Sword:

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: A Valliant sonne in‑law thou shalt enioy:

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: One, fit to bandy with thy lawlesse Sonnes,

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: To ruffle in the Common‑wealth of Rome.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: These words are Razors to my wounded hart

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: And therefore louely {% italic: Tamora %} Queene of Gothes,

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: That like the stately {% italic: Thebe %} mong'st her Nimphs

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: Dost ouer‑shine the Gallant'st Dames of Rome,

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: If thou be pleas'd with this my sodaine choyse,

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: Behold I choose thee {% italic: Tamora %} for my Bride,

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: And will Create thee Empresse of Rome.

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: Speake Queene of Goths dost thou applau'd my choyse?

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: And heere I sweare by all the Romaine Gods,

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: Sith Priest and Holy‑water are so neere,

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: And Tapers burne so bright, and euery thing

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: In readines for {% italic: Hymeneus %} stand,

lines.speaker: Sat.
