lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: A speedier course this lingring languishment

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Must we pursue, and I haue found the path:

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: My Lords, a solemne hunting is in hand.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: There will the louely Roman Ladies troope:

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: The Forrest walkes are wide and spacious,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And many vnfrequented plots there are,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Fitted by kinde for rape and villanie:

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Single you thither then this dainty Doe,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And strike her home by force, if not by words:

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: This way or not at all, stand you in hope.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Come, come, our Empresse with her sacred wit

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: To villainie and vengance consecrate,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Will we acquaint with all that we intend,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And she shall file our engines with aduise,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: That will not suffer you to square your selues,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: But to your wishes height aduance you both.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: The Emperours Court is like the house of Fame,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: The pallace full of tongues, of eyes, of eares:

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: The Woods are ruthlesse, dreadfull, deafe, and dull:

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: There speake, and strike braue Boyes, & take your turnes.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: There serue your lusts, shadow'd from heauens eye,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And reuell in {% italic: Lauinia's %} Treasurie.

lines.speaker: Chi.
lines.text: Thy counsell Lad smells of no cowardise.

lines.speaker: Deme.
lines.text: {% italic: Sit fas aut nefas %}, till I finde the streames,

lines.speaker: Deme.
lines.text: To coole this heat, a Charme to calme their fits,

lines.speaker: Deme.
lines.text: {% italic: Per Stigia per manes Vehor %}.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: The hunt is vp, the morne is bright and gray,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: The fields are fragrant, and the Woods are greene,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Vncouple heere, and let vs make a bay,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And wake the Emperour, and his louely Bride,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And rouze the Prince, and ring a hunters peale,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: That all the Court may eccho with the noyse.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Sonnes let it be your charge, as it is ours,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: To attend the Emperours person carefully:

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: I haue bene troubled in my sleepe this night,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: But dawning day new comfort hath inspir'd.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Many good morrowes to your Maiestie,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Madam to you as many and as good.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: I promised your Grace, a Hunters peale.

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: And you haue rung it lustily my Lords,

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: Somewhat to earely for new married Ladies.

lines.speaker: Bass.
lines.text: {% italic: Lauinia %}, how say you?

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: I say no:

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: I haue bene awake two houres and more.

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: Come on then, horse and Chariots let vs haue,

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: And to our sport: Madam, now shall ye see,

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: Our Romaine hunting.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: I haue dogges my Lord,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Will rouze the proudest Panther in the Chase,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And clime the highest Promontary top.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And I haue horse will follow where the game

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Makes way, and runnes likes Swallowes ore the plaine

lines.speaker: Deme.
lines.text: {% italic: Chiron %} we hunt not we, with Horse nor Hound

lines.speaker: Deme.
lines.text: But hope to plucke a dainty Doe to ground.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: He that had wit, would thinke that I had none,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: To bury so much Gold vnder a Tree,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And neuer after to inherit it.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Let him that thinks of me so abiectly,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Know that this Gold must coine a stratageme,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Which cunningly effected, will beget

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: A very excellent peece of villany:

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And so repose sweet Gold for their vnrest,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: That haue their Almes out of the Empresse Chest.

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: My louely {% italic: Aaron %},

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Wherefore look'st thou sad,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: When euery thing doth make a Gleefull boast?

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: The Birds chaunt melody on euery bush,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: The Snake lies rolled in the chearefull Sunne,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: The greene leaues quiuer, with the cooling winde,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: And make a cheker'd shadow on the ground:

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Vnder their sweete shade, {% italic: Aaron %} let vs sit,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: And whil'st the babling Eccho mock's the Hounds,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Replying shrilly to the well tun'd‑Hornes,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: The A is damaged or partially inked. As if a double hunt were heard at once,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Let vs sit downe, and marke their yelping noyse:

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: And after conflict, such as was suppos'd.

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: The wandring Prince and {% italic: Dido %} once enioy'd,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: When with a happy storme they were surpris'd,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: And Curtain'd with a Counsaile‑keeping Caue,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: We may each wreathed in the others armes,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: (Our pastimes done) possesse a Golden slumber,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Whiles Hounds and Hornes, and sweet Melodious Birds

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Be vnto vs, as is a Nurses Song

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Of Lullabie, to bring her Babe asleepe.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Madame,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Though {% italic: Venus %} gouerne your desires,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Saturne is Dominator ouer mine:

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: What signifies my deadly standing eye,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: My silence, and my Cloudy Melancholie,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: My fleece of Woolly haire, that now vncurles,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Euen as an Adder when she doth vnrowle

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: To do some fatall execution?

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: No Madam, these are no Veneriall signes,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Vengeance is in my heart, death in my hand,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Blood, and reuenge, are Hammering in my head.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Harke {% italic: Tamora %}, the Empresse of my Soule,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Which neuer hopes more heauen, then rests in thee,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: This is the day of Doome for {% italic: Bassianus %};

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: His {% italic: Philomel %} must loose her tongue to day,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Thy Sonnes make Pillage of her Chastity,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And wash their hands in {% italic: Bassianus %} blood.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Seest thou this Letter, take it vp I pray thee,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And giue the King this fatall plotted Scrowle,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Now question me no more, we are espied,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Heere comes a parcell of our hopefull Booty,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Which dreads not yet their liues destruction.

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Ah my sweet {% italic: Moore %}:

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Sweeter to me then life.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: No more great Empresse, {% italic: Bassianus %} comes,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Be crosse with him, and Ile goe fetch thy Sonnes

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: To backe thy quarrell what so ere they be.

lines.speaker: Bassi.
lines.text: Whom haue we heere?

lines.speaker: Bassi.
lines.text: Romes Royall Empresse,

lines.speaker: Bassi.
lines.text: Vnfurnisht of our well beseeming troope?

lines.speaker: Bassi.
lines.text: Or is it {% italic: Dian %} habited like her,

lines.speaker: Bassi.
lines.text: Who hath abandoned her holy Groues,

lines.speaker: Bassi.
lines.text: To see the generall Hunting in this Forrest?

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Sawcie controuler of our priuate steps:

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Had I the power, that some say {% italic: Dian %} had,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Thy Temples should be planted presently.

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: With Hornes, as was {% italic: Acteons %}, and the Hounds

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Should driue vpon his new transformed limbes,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Vnmannerly Intruder as thou art.

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Vnder your patience gentle Empresse,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: 'Tis thought you haue a goodly gift in Horning,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: And to be doubted, that your {% italic: Moore %} and you

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Are singled forth to try experiments:

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: {% italic: Ioue %} sheild your husband from his Hounds to day,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: 'Tis pitty they should take him for a Stag.

lines.speaker: Bassi.
lines.text: Beleeue me Queene, your swarth Cymerion,

lines.speaker: Bassi.
lines.text: Doth make your Honour of his bodies Hue,

lines.speaker: Bassi.
lines.text: Spotted, detested, and abhominable.

lines.speaker: Bassi.
lines.text: Why are you sequestred from all your traine?

lines.speaker: Bassi.
lines.text: Dismounted from your Snow‑white goodly Steed,

lines.speaker: Bassi.
lines.text: And wandred hither to an obscure plot,

lines.speaker: Bassi.
lines.text: Accompanied with a barbarous {% italic: Moore %},

lines.speaker: Bassi.
lines.text: If foule desire had not conducted you?

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: And being intercepted in your sport,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Great reason that my Noble Lord, be rated

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: For Saucinesse, I pray you let vs hence,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: And let her ioy her Rauen coloured loue,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: This valley fits the purpose passing well.

lines.speaker: Bassi.
lines.text: The King my Brother shall haue notice of this.

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: I, for these slips haue made him noted long,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Good King, to be so mightily abused.

lines.speaker: Tamora.
lines.text: Why I haue patience to endure all this?

lines.speaker: Dem.
lines.text: How now deere Soueraigne

lines.speaker: Dem.
lines.text: And our gracious Mother,

lines.speaker: Dem.
lines.text: Why doth your Highnes looke so pale and wan?

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Haue I not reason thinke you to looke pale.

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: These two haue tic'd me hither to this place,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: A barren, detested vale you see it is.

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: The Trees though Sommer, yet forlorne and leane,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Ore‑come with Mosse, and balefull Misselto.

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Heere neuer shines the Sunne, heere nothing breeds,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Vnlesse the nightly Owle, or fatall Rauen:

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: And when they shew'd me this abhorred pit,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: They told me heere at dead time of the night,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: A thousand Fiends, a thousand hissing Snakes,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Ten thousand swelling Toades, as many Vrchins,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Would make such fearefull and confused cries,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: As any mortall body hearing it,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Should straite fall mad, or else die suddenly.

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: No sooner had they told this hellish tale,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: But strait they told me they would binde me heere,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Vnto the body of a dismall yew,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: And leaue me to this miserable death.

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: And then they call'd me foule Adulteresse,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Lasciuious Goth, and all the bitterest tearmes

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: That euer eare did heare to such effect.

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: And had you not by wondrous fortune come,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: This vengeance on me had they executed:

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Reuenge it, as you loue your Mothers life,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Or be ye not henceforth cal'd my Children.

lines.speaker: Dem.
lines.text: This is a witnesse that I am thy Sonne. stab him.

lines.speaker: Chi.
lines.text: And this for me,

lines.speaker: Chi.
lines.text: Strook home to shew my strength.

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: I come {% italic: Semeramis %}, nay Barbarous {% italic: Tamora %}.

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: For no name fits thy nature but thy owne.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Giue me thy poyniard, you shal know my boyes

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Your Mothers hand shall right your Mothers wrong.

lines.speaker: Deme.
lines.text: Stay Madam heere is more belongs to her,

lines.speaker: Deme.
lines.text: First thrash the Corne, then after burne the straw:

lines.speaker: Deme.
lines.text: This Minion stood vpon her chastity,

lines.speaker: Deme.
lines.text: Vpon her Nuptiall vow, her loyaltie.

lines.speaker: Deme.
lines.text: And with that painted hope, braues your Mightinesse,

lines.speaker: Deme.
lines.text: And shall she carry this vnto her graue?

lines.speaker: Chi.
lines.text: And if she doe,

lines.speaker: Chi.
lines.text: I would I were an Eunuch,

lines.speaker: Chi.
lines.text: Drag hence her husband to some secret hole,

lines.speaker: Chi.
lines.text: And make his dead Trunke‑Pillow to our lust.

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: But when ye haue the hony we desire,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Let not this Waspe out‑liue vs both to sting.

lines.speaker: Chir.
lines.text: I warrant you Madam we will make that sure:

lines.speaker: Chir.
lines.text: Come Mistris, now perforce we will enioy,

lines.speaker: Chir.
lines.text: That nice‑preserued honesty of yours.

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Oh {% italic: Tamora %}, thou bear'st a woman face.

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: I will not heare her speake, away with her.

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Sweet Lords intreat her heare me but a word.

lines.speaker: Demet.
lines.text: Listen faire Madam, let it be your glory

lines.speaker: Demet.
lines.text: To see her teares, but be your hart to them,

lines.speaker: Demet.
lines.text: As vnrelenting flint to drops of raine.

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: When did the Tigers young‑ones teach the dam?

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: O doe not learne her wrath, she taught it thee,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: The milke thou suck'st from her did turne to Marble,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Euen at thy Teat thou had'st thy Tyranny,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Yet euery Mother breeds not Sonnes alike,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Do thou intreat her shew a woman pitty.

lines.speaker: Chiro.
lines.text: What,

lines.speaker: Chiro.
lines.text: Would'st thou haue me proue my selfe a bastard?

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: 'Tis true,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: The Rauen doth not hatch a Larke,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Yet haue I heard, Oh could I finde it now,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: The Lion mou'd with pitty, did indure

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: To haue his Princely pawes par'd all away.

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Some say, that Rauens foster forlorne children,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: The whil'st their owne birds famish in their nests:

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Oh be to me though thy hard hart say no,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Nothing so kind but something pittifull.

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: I know not what it meanes, away with her.

lines.speaker: Lauin.
lines.text: Oh let me teach thee for my Fathers sake,

lines.speaker: Lauin.
lines.text: That gaue thee life when well he might haue slaine thee:

lines.speaker: Lauin.
lines.text: Be not obdurate, open thy deafe eares.

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Had'st thou in person nere offended me.

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Euen for his sake am I pittilesse:

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Remember Boyes I powr'd forth teares in vaine,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: To saue your brother from the sacrifice,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: But fierce {% italic: Andronicus %} would not relent,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Therefore away with her, and vse her as you will,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: The worse to her, the better lou'd of me.

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Oh {% italic: Tamora %},

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Be call'd a gentle Queene,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: And with thine owne hands kill me in this place,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: For 'tis not life that I haue beg'd so long,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Poore I was slaine, when Bassianus dy'd.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: What beg'st thou then? fond woman let me go?

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: 'Tis present death I beg, and one thing more,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: That womanhood denies my tongue to tell:

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Oh keepe me from their worse then killing lust,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: And tumble me into some loathsome pit,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Where neuer mans eye may behold my body,

lines.speaker: Laui.
lines.text: Doe this, and be a charitable murderer.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: So should I rob my sweet Sonnes of their fee,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: No let them satisfie their lust on thee.

lines.speaker: Deme.
lines.text: Away,

lines.speaker: Deme.
lines.text: For thou hast staid vs heere too long.

lines.speaker: Lauinia.
lines.text: No Grace,

lines.speaker: Lauinia.
lines.text: No womanhood? Ah beastly creature,

lines.speaker: Lauinia.
lines.text: The blot and enemy to our generall name,

lines.speaker: Lauinia.
lines.text: Confusion fall—

lines.speaker: Chi.
lines.text: Nay then Ile stop your mouth

lines.speaker: Chi.
lines.text: Bring thou her husband,

lines.speaker: Chi.
lines.text: This is the Hole where {% italic: Aaron %} bid vs hide him.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Farewell my Sonnes, see that you make her sure,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Nere let my heart know merry cheere indeed,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Till all the {% italic: Andronici %} be made away:

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Now will I hence to seeke my louely {% italic: Moore %},

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: And let my spleenefull Sonnes this Trull defloure.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Come on my Lords, the better foote before,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Straight will I bring you to the lothsome pit,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Where I espied the Panther fast asleepe.

lines.speaker: Quin.
lines.text: My sight is very dull what ere it bodes.

lines.speaker: Marti.
lines.text: And mine I promise you, were it not for shame,

lines.speaker: Marti.
lines.text: Well could I leaue our sport to sleepe a while.

lines.speaker: Quin.
lines.text: What art thou fallen?

lines.speaker: Quin.
lines.text: What subtile Hole is this,

lines.speaker: Quin.
lines.text: Whose mouth is couered with Rude growing Briers,

lines.speaker: Quin.
lines.text: Vpon whose leaues are drops of new‑shed‑blood,

lines.speaker: Quin.
lines.text: As fresh as mornings dew distil'd on flowers,

lines.speaker: Quin.
lines.text: A very fatall place it seemes to me:

lines.speaker: Quin.
lines.text: Speake Brother hast thou hurt thee with the fall?

lines.speaker: Martius.
lines.text: Oh Brother,

lines.speaker: Martius.
lines.text: With the dismal'st obiect

lines.speaker: Martius.
lines.text: That euer eye with sight made heart lament.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Now will I fetch the King to finde them heere,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: That he thereby may haue a likely gesse,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: How these were they that made away his Brother.

lines.speaker: Marti.
lines.text: Why dost not comfort me and helpe me out,

lines.speaker: Marti.
lines.text: From this vnhallow'd and blood‑stained Hole?

lines.speaker: Quintus.
lines.text: I am surprised with an vncouth feare,

lines.speaker: Quintus.
lines.text: A chilling sweat ore‑runs my trembling ioynts,

lines.speaker: Quintus.
lines.text: My heart suspects more then mine eie can see.

lines.speaker: Marti.
lines.text: To proue thou hast a true diuining heart,

lines.speaker: Marti.
lines.text: {% italic: Aaron %} and thou looke downe into this den,

lines.speaker: Marti.
lines.text: And see a fearefull sight of blood and death.

lines.speaker: Quintus.
lines.text: {% italic: Aaron %} is gone,

lines.speaker: Quintus.
lines.text: And my compassionate heart

lines.speaker: Quintus.
lines.text: Will not permit mine eyes once to behold

lines.speaker: Quintus.
lines.text: The thing where at it trembles by surmise:

lines.speaker: Quintus.
lines.text: Oh tell me how it is, for nere till now

lines.speaker: Quintus.
lines.text: Was I a child to feare I know not what.

lines.speaker: Marti.
lines.text: Lord {% italic: Bassianus %} lies embrewed heere,

lines.speaker: Marti.
lines.text: All on a heape like to the slaughtred Lambe,

lines.speaker: Marti.
lines.text: In this detested, darke, blood‑drinking pit.

lines.speaker: Quin.
lines.text: If it be darke, how doost thou know 'tis he?

lines.speaker: Mart.
lines.text: Vpon his bloody finger he doth weare

lines.speaker: Mart.
lines.text: A precious Ring, that lightens all the Hole:

lines.speaker: Mart.
lines.text: Which like a Taper in some Monument,

lines.speaker: Mart.
lines.text: Doth shine vpon the dead mans earthly cheekes,

lines.speaker: Mart.
lines.text: And shewes the ragged intrailes of the pit:

lines.speaker: Mart.
lines.text: So pale did shine the Moone on {% italic: Piramus %},

lines.speaker: Mart.
lines.text: When he by night lay bath'd in Maiden blood:

lines.speaker: Mart.
lines.text: O Brother helpe me with thy fainting hand.

lines.speaker: Mart.
lines.text: If feare hath made thee faint, as mee it hath,

lines.speaker: Mart.
lines.text: Out of this fell deuouring receptacle,

lines.speaker: Mart.
lines.text: As hatefull as {% italic: Ocitus %} mistie mouth.

lines.speaker: Quint.
lines.text: Reach me thy hand, that I may helpe thee out,

lines.speaker: Quint.
lines.text: Or wanting strength to doe thee so much good,

lines.speaker: Quint.
lines.text: I may be pluckt into the swallowing wombe,

lines.speaker: Quint.
lines.text: Of this deepe pit, poore {% italic: Bassianus %} graue:

lines.speaker: Quint.
lines.text: I haue no strength to plucke thee to the brinke.

lines.speaker: Martius.
lines.text: Nor I no strength to clime without thy help.

lines.speaker: Quin.
lines.text: Thy hand once more, I will not loose againe,

lines.speaker: Quin.
lines.text: Till thou art heere aloft, or I below,

lines.speaker: Quin.
lines.text: Thou can'st not come to me, I come to thee.

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: Along with me, Ile see what hole is heere,

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: And what he is that now is leapt into it.

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: Say, who art thou that lately did'st descend,

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: Into this gaping hollow of the earth?

lines.speaker: Marti.
lines.text: The vnhappie sonne of old {% italic: Andronicus %},

lines.speaker: Marti.
lines.text: Brought hither in a most vnluckie houre,

lines.speaker: Marti.
lines.text: To finde thy brother {% italic: Bassianus %} dead.

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: My brother dead? I know thou dost but iest,

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: He and his Lady both are at the Lodge,

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: Vpon the North‑side of this pleasant Chase,

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: 'Tis not an houre since I left him there.

lines.speaker: Marti.
lines.text: We know not where you left him all aliue,

lines.speaker: Marti.
lines.text: But out alas, heere haue we found him dead.

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Where is my Lord the King?

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Heere {% italic: Tamora %}, though grieu'd with killing griefe.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Where is thy brother {% italic: Bassianus %}?

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Now to the bottome dost thou search my wound,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Poore {% italic: Bassianus %} heere lies murthered.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Then all too late I bring this fatall writ,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: The complot of this timelesse Tragedie,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: And wonder greatly that mans face can fold,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: In pleasing smiles such murderous Tyrannie.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Oh {% italic: Tamora %}, was euer heard the like?

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: This is the pit, and this the Elder tree,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Looke sirs, if you can finde the huntsman out,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: That should haue murthered {% italic: Bassianus %} heere.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: My gracious Lord heere is the bag of Gold.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Two of thy whelpes, fell Curs of bloody kind

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Haue heere bereft my brother of his life:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Sirs drag them from the pit vnto the prison,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: There let them bide vntill we haue deuis'd

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Some neuer heard‑of tortering paine for them.

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: What are they in this pit,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Oh wondrous thing!

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: How easily murder is discouered?

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: High Emperour, vpon my feeble knee,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: I beg this boone, with teares, not lightly shed,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: That this fell fault of my accursed Sonnes,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Accursed, if the faults be prou'd in them.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: If it be prou'd? you see it is apparant,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Who found this Letter, {% italic: Tamora %} was it you?

lines.speaker: Tamora.
lines.text: {% italic: Andronicus %} himselfe did take it vp.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: I did my Lord,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Yet let me be their baile,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: For by my Fathers reuerent Tombe I vow

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: They shall be ready at your Highnes will,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: To answere their suspition with their liues.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Thou shalt not baile them, see thou follow me:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Some bring the murthered body, some the murtherers,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Let them not speake a word, the guilt is plaine,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: For by my soule, were there worse end then death,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: That end vpon them should be executed.

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: {% italic: Andronicus %} I will entreat the King,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Feare not thy Sonnes, they shall do well enough.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Come Lucius come,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Stay not to talke with them.

lines.speaker: Deme.
lines.text: So now goe tell and if thy tongue can speake,

lines.speaker: Deme.
lines.text: Who t'was that cut thy tongue and rauisht thee.

lines.speaker: Chi.
lines.text: Write downe thy mind, bewray thy meaning so,

lines.speaker: Chi.
lines.text: And if thy stumpes will let thee play the Scribe.

lines.speaker: Dem.
lines.text: See how with signes and tokens she can scowle.

lines.speaker: Chi.
lines.text: Goe home,

lines.speaker: Chi.
lines.text: Call for sweet water, wash thy hands.

lines.speaker: Dem.
lines.text: She hath no tongue to call, nor hands to wash.

lines.speaker: Dem.
lines.text: And so let's leaue her to her silent walkes.

lines.speaker: Chi.
lines.text: And t'were my cause, I should goe hang my selfe.

lines.speaker: Dem.
lines.text: If thou had'st hands to helpe thee knit the cord.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Heare me graue fathers, noble Tribunes stay,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: For pitty of mine age, whose youth was spent

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: In dangerous warres, whilst you securely slept:

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: For all my blood in Romes great quarrell shed,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: For all the frosty nights that I haue watcht,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: And for these bitter teares, which now you see,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Filling the aged wrinkles in my cheekes,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Be pittifull to my condemned Sonnes,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Whose soules is not corrupted as 'tis thought:

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: For two and twenty sonnes I neuer wept,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Because they died in honours lofty bed.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: For these, Tribunes, in the dust I write

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: My harts deepe languor, and my soules sad teares:

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Let my teares stanch the earths drie appetite.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: My sonnes sweet blood, will make it shame and blush:

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: O earth! I will be friend thee more with raine

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: That shall distill from these two ancient ruines,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Then youthfull Aprill shall with all his showres

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: In summers drought: Ile drop vpon thee still,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: In Winter with warme teares Ile melt the snow,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: And keepe eternall spring time on thy face,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: So thou refuse to drinke my deare sonnes blood.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Oh noble father, you lament in vaine,

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: The Tribunes heare not, no man is by,

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: And you recount your sorrowes to a stone.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Ah {% italic: Lucius %} for thy brothers let me plead,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Graue Tribunes, once more I intreat of you.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: My gracious Lord, no Tribune heares you speake.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Why 'tis no matter man, if they did heare

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: They would not marke me: oh if they did heare

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: They would not pitty me.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Therefore I tell my sorrowes bootles to the stones.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Who though they cannot answere my distresse,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Yet in some sort they are better then the Tribunes,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: For that they will not intercept my tale;

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: When I doe weepe, they humbly at my feete

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Receiue my teares, and seeme to weepe with me,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: And were they but attired in graue weedes,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Rome could afford no Tribune like to these.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: A stone is as soft waxe,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Tribunes more hard then stones:

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: A stone is silent, and offendeth not,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: And Tribunes with their tongues doome men to death.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: But wherefore stand'st thou with thy weapon drawne?

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: To rescue my two brothers from their death,

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: For which attempt the Iudges haue pronounc'st

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: My euerlasting doome of banishment.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: O happy man, they haue befriended thee:

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Why foolish {% italic: Lucius %}, dost thou not perceiue

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: That Rome is but a wildernes of Tigers?

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Tigers must pray, and Rome affords no prey

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: But me and mine: how happy art thou then,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: From these deuourers to be banished?

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: But who comes with our brother {% italic: Marcus %} heere?

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: {% italic: Titus %}, prepare thy noble eyes to weepe,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Or if not so, thy noble heart to breake:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: I bring consuming sorrow to thine age.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Will it consume me? Let me see it then.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: This was thy daughter.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Why {% italic: Marcus %} so she is.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Aye me this obiect kils me.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Faint‑harted boy, arise and looke vpon her,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Speake {% italic: Lauinia %}, what accursed hand

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Hath made thee handlesse in thy Fathers sight?

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: What foole hath added water to the Sea?

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Or brought a faggot to bright burning Troy?

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: My griefe was at the height before thou cam'st,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: And now like {% italic: Nylus %} it disdaineth bounds:

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Giue me a sword, Ile chop off my hands too,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: For they haue fought for Rome, and all in vaine:

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: And they haue nur'st this woe,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: In feeding life:

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: In bootelesse prayer haue they bene held vp,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: And they haue seru'd me to effectlesse vse.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Now all the seruice I require of them,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Is that the one will helpe to cut the other:

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: 'Tis well {% italic: Lauinia %}, that thou hast no hands,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: For hands to do Rome seruice, is but vaine.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Speake gentle sister, who hath martyr'd thee?

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: O that delightfull engine of her thoughts,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: That blab'd them with such pleasing eloquence,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Is torne from forth that pretty hollow cage,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Where like a sweet mellodius bird it sung,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Sweet varied notes inchanting euery eare.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Oh say thou for her,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Who hath done this deed?

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: Oh thus I found her straying in the Parke,

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: Seeking to hide herselfe as doth the Deare

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: That hath receiude some vnrecuring wound.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: It was my Deare,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And he that wounded her,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Hath hurt me more, then had he kild me dead:

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: For now I stand as one vpon a Rocke,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Inuiron'd with a wildernesse of Sea.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Who markes the waxing tide,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Grow waue by waue,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Expecting euer when some enuious surge,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Will in his brinish bowels swallow him.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: This way to death my wretched sonnes are gone:

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Heere stands my other sonne, a banisht man,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And heere my brother weeping at my woes.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: But that which giues my soule the greatest spurne,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Is deere {% italic: Lauinia %}, deerer then my soule.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Had I but seene thy picture in this plight,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: It would haue madded me. What shall I doe?

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Now I behold thy liuely body so?

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Thou hast no hands to wipe away thy teares,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Nor tongue to tell me who hath martyr'd thee:

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Thy husband he is dead, and for his death

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Thy brothers are condemn'd, and dead by this.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Looke {% italic: Marcus %}, ah sonne {% italic: Lucius %} looke on her:

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: When I did name her brothers, then fresh teares

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Stood on her cheekes, as doth the hony dew,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Vpon a gathred Lillie almost withered.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Perchance she weepes because they kil'd her

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Perchance because she knowes him innocent.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: If they did kill thy husband then be ioyfull,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Because the law hath tane reuenge on them.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: No, no, they would not doe so foule a deede,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Witnes the sorrow that their sister makes.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Gentle {% italic: Lauinia %} let me kisse thy lips,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Or make some signes how I may do thee ease:

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Shall thy good Vncle, and thy brother {% italic: Lucius %},

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: And thou and I sit round about some Fountaine,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Looking all downewards to behold our cheekes

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: How they are stain'd in meadowes, yet not dry

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: With miery slime left on them by a flood:

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: And in the Fountaine shall we gaze so long,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Till the fresh taste be taken from that cleerenes,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: And made a brine pit with our bitter teares?

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Or shall we cut away our hands like thine?

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Or shall we bite our tongues, and in dumbe shewes

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Passe the remainder of our hatefull dayes?

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: What shall we doe? Let vs that haue our tongues

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Plot some deuise of further miseries

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: To make vs wondred at in time to come.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Sweet Father cease your teares, for at your griefe

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: See how my wretched sister sobs and weeps.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Patience deere Neece, good {% italic: Titus %} drie thine

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Ah {% italic: Marcus %}, {% italic: Marcus %}, Brother well I wot,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Thy napkin cannot drinke a teare of mine,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: For thou poore man hast drown'd it with thine owne.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Ah my {% italic: Lauinia %} I will wipe thy cheekes.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Marke {% italic: Marcus %} marke, I vnderstand her signes,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Had she a tongue to speake, now would she say

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: That to her brother which I said to thee.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: His Napkin with her true teares all bewet,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Can do no seruice on her sorrowfull cheekes.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Oh what a simpathy of woe is this!

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: As farre from helpe as Limbo is from blisse,

lines.speaker: Moore.
lines.text: {% italic: Titus Andronicus %}, my Lord the Emperour,

lines.speaker: Moore.
lines.text: Sends thee this word, that if thou loue thy sonnes,

lines.speaker: Moore.
lines.text: Let {% italic: Marcus, Lucius, %} or thy selfe old {% italic: Titus %},

lines.speaker: Moore.
lines.text: Or any one of you, chop off your hand,

lines.speaker: Moore.
lines.text: And send it to the King: he for the same,

lines.speaker: Moore.
lines.text: Will send thee hither both thy sonnes aliue,

lines.speaker: Moore.
lines.text: And that shall be the ransome for their fault.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Oh gracious Emperour, oh gentle {% italic: Aaron %}.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Did euer Rauen sing so like a Larke,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: That giues sweet tydings of the Sunnes vprise?

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: With all my heart, Ile send the Emperour my hand,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Good {% italic: Aron %} wilt thou help to chop it off?

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Stay Father, for that noble hand of thine,

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: That hath throwne downe so many enemies,

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Shall not be sent: my hand will serue the turne,

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: My youth can better spare my blood then you,

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: And therfore mine shall saue my brothers liues.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Which of your hands hath not defended Rome,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And rear'd aloft the bloody Battleaxe,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Writing destruction on the enemies Castle?

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Oh none of both but are of high desert:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: My hand hath bin but idle, let it serue

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: To ransome my two nephewes from their death,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Then haue I kept it to a worthy end.

lines.speaker: Moore.
lines.text: Nay come agree, whose hand shall goe along

lines.speaker: Moore.
lines.text: For feare they die before their pardon come.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: My hand shall goe.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: By heauen it shall not goe.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Sirs striue no more, such withered hearbs as these

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Are meete for plucking vp, and therefore mine.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Sweet Father, if I shall be thought thy sonne,

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Let me redeeme my brothers both from death.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And for our fathers sake, and mothers care,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Now let me shew a brothers loue to thee.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Agree betweene you, I will spare my hand.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Then Ile goe fetch an Axe.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: But I will vse the Axe.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Come hither {% italic: Aaron %}, Ile deceiue them both,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Lend me thy hand, and I will giue thee mine,

lines.speaker: Moore.
lines.text: If that be cal'd deceit, I will be honest,

lines.speaker: Moore.
lines.text: And neuer whil'st I liue deceiue men so:

lines.speaker: Moore.
lines.text: But Ile deceiue you in another sort,

lines.speaker: Moore.
lines.text: And that you'l say ere halfe an houre passe.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Now stay you strife, what shall be, is dispatcht:

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Good {% italic: Aron %} giue his Maiestie me hand,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Tell him, it was a hand that warded him

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: From thousand dangers: bid him bury it:

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: More hath it merited: That let it haue.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: As for my sonnes, say I account of them,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: As iewels purchast at an easie price,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: And yet deere too, because I bought mine owne.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: I goe {% italic: Andronicus %}, and for thy hand,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Looke by and by to haue thy sonnes with thee:

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Their heads I meane: Oh how this villany

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Doth fat me with the very thoughts of it.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Let fooles doe good, and faire men call for grace,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: {% italic: Aron %} will haue his soule blacke like his face.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: O heere I lift this one hand vp to heauen,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: And bow this feeble ruine to the earth,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: If any power pitties wretched teares,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: To that I call: what wilt thou kneele with me?

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Doe then deare heart, for heauen shall heare our prayers,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Or with our sighs weele breath the welkin dimme,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: And staine the Sun with fogge as somtime cloudes,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: When they do hug him in their melting bosomes.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Oh brother speake with possibilities,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And do not breake into these deepe extreames.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Is not my sorrow deepe, hauing no bottome?

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Then be my passions bottomlesse with them.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: But yet let reason gouerne thy lament.

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: If there were reason for these miseries,

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: Then into limits could I binde my woes:

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: When heauen doth weepe, doth not the earth oreflow?

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: If the windes rage, doth not the Sea wax mad,

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: Threatning the welkin with his big‑swolne face?

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: And wilt thou haue a reason for this coile?

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: I am the Sea. Harke how her sighes doe flow:

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: Shee is the weeping welkin, I the earth:

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: Then must my Sea be moued with her sighes,

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: Then must my earth with her continuall teares,

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: Become a deluge: ouerflow'd and drown'd:

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: For why, my bowels cannot hide her woes,

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: But like a drunkard must I vomit them:

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: Then giue me leaue, for loosers will haue leaue,

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: To ease their stomackes with their bitter tongues,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Worthy {% italic: Andronicus %}, ill art thou repaid,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: For that good hand thou sentst the Emperour:

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Heere are the heads of thy two noble sonnes.

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: And heeres thy hand in scorne to thee sent backe:

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Thy griefes, their sports: Thy resolution mockt,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: That woe is me to thinke vpon thy woes,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: More then remembrance of my fathers death.

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: Now let hot ætna coole in Cicilie,

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: And be my heart an euer‑burning hell:

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: These miseries are more then may be borne.

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: To weepe with them that weepe, doth ease some deale,

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: But sorrow flouted at, is double death.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Ah that this sight should make so deep a wound,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: And yet detested life not shrinke thereat:

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: That euer death should let life beare his name,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Where life hath no more interest but to breath.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Alas poore hart that kisse is comfortlesse,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: As frozen water to a starued snake.

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: When will this fearefull slumber haue an end?

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Now farwell flatterie, die {% italic: Andronicus %},

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Thou dost not slumber, see thy two sons heads,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Thy warlike hands, thy mangled daughter here:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Thy other banisht sonnes with this deere sight

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Strucke pale and bloodlesse, and thy brother I,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Euen like a stony Image, cold and numme.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Ah now no more will I controule my griefes,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Rent off thy siluer haire, thy other hand

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Gnawing with thy teeth, and be this dismall sight

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: The closing vp of our most wretched eyes:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Now is a time to storme, why art thou still?

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: Ha, ha, ha,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Why dost thou laugh? it fits not with this houre.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Why I haue not another teare to shed:

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Besides, this sorrow is an enemy,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: And would vsurpe vpon my watry eyes,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: And make them blinde with tributarie teares.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Then which way shall I finde Reuenges Caue?

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: For these two heads doe seeme to speake to me,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: And threat me, I shall neuer come to blisse,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Till all these mischiefes be returned againe,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Euen in their throats that haue committed them.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Come let me see what taske I haue to doe,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: You heauie people, circle me about,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: That I may turne me to each one of you,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: And sweare vnto my soule to right your wrongs.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: The vow is made, come Brother take a head,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: And in this hand the other will I beare.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: And {% italic: Lauinia %} thou shalt be employd in these things:

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Beare thou my hand sweet wench betweene thy teeth:

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: As for thee boy, goe get thee from my sight,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Thou art an Exile, and thou must not stay,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Hie to the {% italic: Gothes %}, and raise an army there,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: And if you loue me, as I thinke you doe,

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Let's kisse and part, for we haue much to doe.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Farewell {% italic: Andronicus %} my noble Father:

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: The woful'st man that euer liu'd in Rome:

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Farewell proud Rome, til {% italic: Lucius %} come againe,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: He loues his pledges dearer then his life:

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Farewell {% italic: Lauinia %} my noble sister,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: O would thou wert as thou to fore hast beene,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: But now, nor {% italic: Lucius %} nor {% italic: Lauinia %} liues

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: But in obliuion and hateful griefes:

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: If {% italic: Lucius %} liue, he will requit your wrongs,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: And make proud {% italic: Saturnine %} and his Empresse

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Beg at the gates like {% italic: Tarquin %} and his Queene.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Now will I to the Gothes and raise a power,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: To be reueng'd on Rome and {% italic: Saturnine %}.

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: So, so, now sit, and looke you eate no more

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Then will preserue iust so much strength in vs

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: As will reuenge these bitter woes of ours.

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: {% italic: Marcus %} vnknit that sorrow‑wreathen knot:

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Thy Neece and I (poore Creatures) want our hands

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: And cannot passionate our tenfold griefe,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: With foulded Armes. This poore right hand of mine,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Is left to tirranize vppon my breast.

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Who when my hart all mad with misery,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Beats in this hollow prison of my flesh,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Then thus I thumpe it downe.

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Thou Map of woe, that thus dost talk in signes,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: When thy poore hart beates without ragious beating,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Thou canst not strike it thus to make it still?

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Wound it with sighing girle, kil it with grones:

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Or get some little knife betweene thy teeth,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: And iust against thy hart make thou a hole,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: That all the teares that thy poore eyes let fall

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: May run into that sinke, and soaking in,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Drowne the lamenting foole, in Sea salt teares.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Fy brother fy, teach her not thus to lay

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Such violent hands vppon her tender life.

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: How now! Has sorrow made thee doate already?

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Why {% italic: Marcus %}, no man should be mad but I:

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: What violent hands can she lay on her life:

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Ah, wherefore dost thou vrge the name of hands,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: To bid {% italic: æneas %} tell the tale twice ore

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: How Troy was burnt, and he made miserable?

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: O handle not the theame, to talke of hands,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Least we remember still that we haue none,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Fie, fie, how Frantiquely I square my talke

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: As if we should forget we had no hands:

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: If {% italic: Marcus %} did not name the word of hands.

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Come, lets fall too, and gentle girle eate this,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Heere is no drinke? Harke {% italic: Marcus %} what she saies,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: I can interpret all her martir'd signes,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: She saies, she drinkes no other drinke but teares

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Breu'd with her sorrow: mesh'd vppon her cheekes,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Speechlesse complayner, I will learne thy thought:

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: In thy dumb action, will I be as perfect

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: As begging Hermits in their holy prayers.

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Thou shalt not sighe nor hold thy stumps to heauen,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Nor winke, nor nod, nor kneele, nor make a signe;

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: But I (of these) will wrest an Alphabet,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: And by still practice, learne to know thy meaning.

lines.speaker: Boy.
lines.text: Good grandsire leaue these bitter deepe laments,

lines.speaker: Boy.
lines.text: Make my Aunt merry, with some pleasing tale.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Alas, the tender boy in passion mou'd,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Doth weepe to see his grandsires heauinesse.

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Peace tender Sapling, thou art made of teares,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: And teares will quickly melt thy life away.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: At that that I haue kil'd my Lord, a Flys

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Out on the murderour: thou kil'st my hart,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Mine eyes cloi'd with view of Tirranie:

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: A deed of death done on the Innocent

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Becoms not {% italic: Titus %} brother: get thee gone,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: I see thou art not for my company.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Alas (my Lord) I haue but kild a flie.

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: But? How: if that Flie had a father and mother?

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: How would he hang his slender gilded wings

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: And buz lamenting doings in the ayer,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Poore harmelesse Fly,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: That with his pretty buzing melody,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Came heere to make vs merry,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: And thou hast kil'd him.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Pardon me sir,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: It was a blacke illfauour'd Fly,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Like to the Empresse Moore, therefore I kild him.

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: O, o, o,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Then pardon me for reprehending thee,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: For thou hast done a Charitable deed:

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Giue me thy knife, I will insult on him,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Flattering my selfes, as if it were the Moore,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Come hither purposely to poyson me.

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: There's for thy selfe, and thats for {% italic: Tamira %}: Ah sirra,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Yet I thinke we are not brought so low,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: But that betweene vs, we can kill a Fly,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: That comes in likenesse of a Cole‑blacke Moore.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Alas poore man, griefe ha's so wrought on him,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: He takes false shadowes, for true substances.

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Come, take away: {% italic: Lauinia %}, goe with me,

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Ile to thy closset, and goe read with thee

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Sad stories, chanced in the times of old.

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Come boy, and goe with me, thy sight is young,

lines.speaker: An.

lines.text: Followes me euery where I know not why.

lines.text: I when my father was in Rome she did.

lines.speaker: Ti.
lines.text: Some whether would she haue thee goe with her.

lines.text: Sweet Poetry, and Tullies Oratour:

lines.text: My Lord I know not I, nor can I gesse,

lines.text: Vnlesse some fit or frenzie do possesse her:

lines.text: For I haue heard my Gransier say full oft,

lines.speaker: Boy.

lines.text: Ran mad through sorrow, that made me to feare,

lines.text: Although my Lord, I know my noble Aunt,

lines.text: Loues me as deare as ere my mother did,

lines.text: Which made me downe to throw my bookes, and flie

lines.text: young dayes. Why I am going with my pigeons to the
