lines.text: Tribunall Plebs, to take vp a matter of brawle, betwixt

lines.speaker: Clowne.
lines.text: my Vncle, and one of the Emperialls men.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Why sir, that is as fit as can be to serue for your

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Oration, and let him deliuer the Pigions to the Emperour

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Tell mee, can you deliuer an Oration to the Em­

lines.speaker: Clowne.
lines.text: Nay truely sir, I could neuer say grace in all

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Sirrah come hither, make no more adoe,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: But giue your Pigeons to the Emperour,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: By me thou shalt haue Iustice at his hands.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Hold, hold, meane while her's money for thy charges.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Giue me pen and inke.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Sirrah, can you with a Grace deliuer a Supplication?

lines.speaker: Clowne.
lines.text: I sir

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: Then here is a Supplication for you, and when

lines.speaker: Clowne.
lines.text: I warrant you sir, let me alone.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Sirrha hast thou a knife? Come let me see it.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Heere {% italic: Marcus %}, fold it in the Oration,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: For thou hast made it like an humble Suppliant:

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And when thou hast giuen it the Emperour,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Knocke at my dore, and tell me what he sayes.

lines.speaker: Clowne.
lines.text: God be with you sir, I will.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Come {% italic: Marcus %} let vs goe, {% italic: Publius %} follow me.

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: Why Lords,

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: An Emperour in Rome thus ouerborne,

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: Troubled, Confronted thus, and for the extent

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: Of eg all iustice, vs'd in such contempt?

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: My Lords, you know the mightfull Gods,

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: (How euer these disturbers of our peace

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: Buz in the peoples eares) there nought hath past,

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: But euen with law against the willfull Sonnes

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: Of old {% italic: Andronicus %}. And what and if

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: His sorrowes haue so ouerwhelm'd his wits,

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: Shall we be thus afflicted in his wreakes,

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: His fits, his frenzie, and his bitternesse?

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: And now he writes to heauen for his redresse.

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: See, heeres to {% italic: Ioue %}, and this to {% italic: Mercury %},

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: This to {% italic: Apollo %}, this to the God of warre:

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: Sweet scrowles to flie about the streets of Rome:

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: What's this but Libelling against the Senate,

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: And blazoning our Iniustice euery where?

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: A goodly humour, is it not my Lords?

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: As who would say, in Rome no Iustice were.

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: But if I liue, his fained extasies

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: Shall be no shelter to these outrages:

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: But he and his shall know, that Iustice liues

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: In {% italic: Saturninus %} health; whom if he sleepe,

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: Hee'l so awake, as he in fury shall

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: Cut off the proud'st Conspirator that liues.

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: My gracious Lord, my louely {% italic: Saturnine %},

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Lord of my life, Commander of my thoughts,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Calme thee, and beare the faults of {% italic: Titus %} age,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Th' effects of sorrow for his valiant Sonnes,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Whose losse hath pier'st him deepe, and scar'd his heart;

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: And rather comfort his distressed plight,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Then prosecute the meanest or the best

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: For these contempts. Why thus it shall become

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: High witted {% italic: Tamora %} to glose with all:

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: But {% italic: Titus %}, I haue touch'd thee to the quicke,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Thy life blood out: If {% italic: Aaron %} now be wise,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Then is all safe, the Anchor's in the Port.

lines.speaker: Clow.
lines.text: Yea forsooth, and your Mistership be Emperiall.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Empresse I am, but yonder sits the Emperour.

lines.speaker: Clo.
lines.text: 'Tis he; God & Saint Stephen giue you good den;

lines.speaker: Clo.
lines.text: I haue brought you a Letter, & a couple of Pigions heere.

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Goe take him away, and hang him presently.

lines.speaker: Clowne.
lines.text: How much money must I haue?

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Come sirrah you must be hang'd.

lines.speaker: Clow.
lines.text: Hang'd? ber Lady, then I haue brought vp a neck

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Despightfull and intollerable wrongs,

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Shall I endure this monstrous villany?

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: I know from whence this same deuise proceedes:

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: May this be borne? As if his traytrous Sonnes,

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: That dy'd by law for murther of our Brother,

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Haue by my meanes beene butcher'd wrongfully?

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Goe dragge the villaine hither by the haire,

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Nor Age, nor Honour, shall shape priuiledge:

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: For this proud mocke, Ile be thy slaughter man:

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Sly franticke wretch, that holp'st to make me great,

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: In hope thy selfe should gouerne Rome and me.

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: What newes with thee {% italic: Emillius %}?

lines.speaker: Emil.
lines.text: Arme my Lords, Rome neuer had more cause,

lines.speaker: Emil.
lines.text: The Gothes haue gather'd head, and with a power

lines.speaker: Emil.
lines.text: Of high resolued men, bent to the spoyle

lines.speaker: Emil.
lines.text: They hither march amaine, vnder conduct

lines.speaker: Emil.
lines.text: Of {% italic: Lucius %}, Sonne to old {% italic: Andronicus %}:

lines.speaker: Emil.
lines.text: Who threats in course of this reuenge to do

lines.speaker: Emil.
lines.text: As much as euer {% italic: Coriolanus %} did.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Is warlike {% italic: Lucius %} Generall of the Gothes?

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: These tydings nip me, and I hang the head

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: As flowers with frost, or grasse beat downe with stormes:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: I, now begins our sorrowes to approach,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: 'Tis he the common people loue so much,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: My selfe hath often heard them say,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: (When I haue walked like a priuate man)

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: That {% italic: Lucius %} banishment was wrongfully,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And they haue wisht that {% italic: Lucius %} were their Emperour.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Why should you feare? Is not our City strong?

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: I, but the Cittizens fauour {% italic: Lucius %},

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And will reuolt from me, to succour him.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: {% italic: King %}, be thy thoughts Imperious like thy name.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Is the Sunne dim'd, that Gnats do flie in it?

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: The Eagle suffers little Birds to sing,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: And is not carefull what they meane thereby,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Knowing that with the shadow of his wings,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: He can at pleasure stint their melodie.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Euen so mayest thou, the giddy men of Rome,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Then cheare thy spirit, for know thou Emperour,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: I will enchaunt the old {% italic: Andronicus %},

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: With words more sweet, and yet more dangerous

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Then baites to fish, or hony stalkes to sheepe,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: When as the one is wounded with the baite,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: The other rotted with delicious foode.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: But he will not entreat his Sonne for vs.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: If {% italic: Tamora %} entreat him, then he will,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: For I can smooth and fill his aged eare,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: With golden promises, that were his heart

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Almost Impregnable, his old eares deafe,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Yet should both eare and heart obey my tongue.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Goe thou before to our Embassadour,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Say, that the Emperour requests a parly

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Of warlike {% italic: Lucius %}, and appoint the meeting.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: {% italic: Emillius %} do this message Honourably,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And if he stand in Hostage for his safety,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Bid him demaund what pledge will please him best.

lines.speaker: Emill.
lines.text: Your bidding shall I do effectually.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Now will I to that old {% italic: Andronicus %},

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: And temper him with all the Art I haue,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: To plucke proud {% italic: Lucius %} from the warlike Gothes.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: And now sweet Emperour be blithe againe,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: And bury all thy feare in my deuises.

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Then goe successantly and plead for him.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Approued warriours, and my faithfull Friends,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: I haue receiued Letters from great Rome,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Which signifies what hate they beare their Emperour,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: And how desirous of our sight they are.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Therefore great Lords, be as your Titles witnesse,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Imperious and impatient of your wrongs,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: And wherein Rome hath done you any scathe,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Let him make treble satisfaction.

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Braue slip, sprung from the Great {% italic: Andronicus %},

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Whose name was once our terrour, now our comfort,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Whose high exploits, and honourable Deeds,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Ingratefull Rome requites with foule contempt:

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Behold in vs, weele follow where thou lead'st,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Like stinging Bees in hottest Sommers day,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Led by their Maister to the flowred fields,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: And be aueng'd on cursed {% italic: Tamora %}:

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: And as he saith, so say we all with him.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: I humbly thanke him, and I thanke you all.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: But who comes heere, led by a lusty {% italic: Goth %}?

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Renowned {% italic: Lucius %}, from our troups I straid,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: To gaze vpon a ruinous Monasterie,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: And as I earnestly did fixe mine eye

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Vpon the wasted building, suddainely

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: I heard a childe cry vnderneath a wall:

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: I made vnto the noyse, when soone I heard,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: The crying babe control'd with this discourse:

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Peace Tawny slaue, halfe me, and halfe thy Dam,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Did not thy Hue bewray whose brat thou art?

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Had nature lent thee, but thy Mothers looke,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Villaine thou might'st haue bene an Emperour.

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: But where the Bull and Cow are both milk‑white,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: They neuer do beget a cole‑blacke‑Calfe:

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Peace, villaine peace, euen thus he rates the babe,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: For I must beare thee to a trusty Goth,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Who when he knowes thou art the Empresse babe,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Will hold thee dearely for thy Mothers sake.

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: With this, my weapon drawne I rusht vpon him,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Surpriz'd him suddainely, and brought him hither

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: To vse, as you thinke needefull of the man.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Oh worthy Goth, this is the incarnate deuill,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: That rob'd {% italic: Andronicus %} of his good hand:

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: This is the Pearle that pleas'd your Empresse eye,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: And heere's the Base Fruit of his burning lust.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Say wall‑ey'd slaue, whether would'st thou conuay

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: This growing Image of thy fiend‑like face?

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Why dost not speake? what deafe? Not a word?

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: A halter Souldiers, hang him on this Tree,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: And by his side his Fruite of Bastardie.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Touch not the Boy, he is of Royall blood.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Too like the Syre for euer being good.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: First hang the Child that he may see it sprall,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: A sight to vexe the Fathers soule withall.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Get me a Ladder {% italic: Lucius %}, saue the Childe,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And beare it from me to the Empresse:

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: If thou do this, Ile shew thee wondrous things,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: That highly may aduantage thee to heare;

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: If thou wilt not, befall what may befall,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Ile speake no more: but vengeance rot you all.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Say on, and if it please me which thou speak'st,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Thy child shall liue, and I will see it Nourisht.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And if it please thee? why assure thee {% italic: Lucius %},

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: 'Twill vexe thy soule to heare what I shall speake:

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: For I must talke of Murthers, Rapes, and Massacres,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Acts of Blacke‑night, abhominable Deeds,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Complots of Mischiefe, Treason, Villanies

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Ruthfull to heare, yet pittiously preform'd,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And this shall all be buried by my death,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Vnlesse thou sweare to me my Childe shall liue.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Tell on thy minde,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: I say thy Childe shall liue.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Sweare that he shall, and then I will begin.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Who should I sweare by,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Thou beleeuest no God,

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: That graunted, how can'st thou beleeue an oath?

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: What if I do not, as indeed I do not,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Yet for I know thou art Religious,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And hast a thing within thee, called Conscience,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: With twenty Popish trickes and Ceremonies,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Which I haue seene thee carefull to obserue:

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Therefore I vrge thy oath, for that I know

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: An Ideot holds his Bauble for a God,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And keepes the oath which by that God he sweares,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: To that Ile vrge him: therefore thou shalt vow

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: By that same God, what God so ere it be

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: That thou adorest, and hast in reuerence,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: To saue my Boy, to nourish and bring him vp,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Ore else I will discouer nought to thee.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Euen by my God I sweare to thee I will.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: First know thou,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: I begot him on the Empresse.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Oh most Insatiate luxurious woman!

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Tut {% italic: Lucius %}, this was but a deed of Charitie,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: To that which thou shalt heare of me anon,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: 'Twas her two Sonnes that murdered {% italic: Bassianus %},

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: They cut thy Sisters tongue, and rauisht her,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And cut her hands off, and trim'd her as thou saw'st.

lines.speaker: Lucius.
lines.text: Oh detestable villaine!

lines.speaker: Lucius.
lines.text: Call'st thou that Trimming?

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Why she was washt, and cut, and trim'd,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And 'twas trim sport for them that had the doing of it.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Oh barbarous beastly villaines like thy selfe!

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Indeede, I was their Tutor to instruct them

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: That Codding spirit had they from their Mother,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: As sure a Card as euer wonne the Set:

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: That bloody minde I thinke they learn'd of me,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: As true a Dog as euer fought at head.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Well, let my Deeds be witnesse of my worth:

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: I trayn'd thy Bretheren to that guilefull Hole,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Where the dead Corps of {% italic: Bassianus %} lay:

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: I wrote the Letter, that thy Father found,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And hid the Gold within the Letter mention'd.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Confederate with the Queene, and her two Sonnes,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And what not done, that thou hast cause to rue,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Wherein I had no stroke of Mischeife in it.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: I play'd the Cheater for thy Fathers hand,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And when I had it, drew my selfe apart,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And almost broke my heart with extreame laughter.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: I pried me through the Creuice of a Wall,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: When for his hand, he had his two Sonnes heads,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Beheld his teares, and laught so hartily,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: That both mine eyes were rainie like to his:

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And when I told the Empresse of this sport,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: She sounded almost at my pleasing tale,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And for my tydings, gaue me twenty kisses.

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: What canst thou say all this, and neuer blush?

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: I, like a blacke Dogge, as the saying is.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Art thou not sorry for these hainous deedes?

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: I, that I had not done a thousand more:

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Euen now I curse the day, and yet I thinke

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Few come within few compasse of my curse,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Wherein I did not some Notorious ill,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: As kill a man, or else deuise his death,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Rauish a Maid, or plot the way to do it,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Accuse some Innocent, and forsweare my selfe,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Set deadly Enmity betweene two Friends,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Make poore mens Cattell breake their neckes,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Set fire on Barnes and Haystackes in the night,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And bid the Owners quench them with the teares:

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Oft haue I dig'd vp dead men from their graues,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And set them vpright at their deere Friends doore,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Euen when their sorrowes almost was forgot,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And on their skinnes, as on the Barke of Trees,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Haue with my knife carued in Romaine Letters,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Let not your sorrow die, though I am dead.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Tut, I haue done a thousand dreadfull things

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: As willingly, as one would kill a Fly,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And nothing greeues me hartily indeede,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: But that I cannot doe ten thousand more.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Bring downe the diuell, for he must not die

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: So sweet a death as hanging presently.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: If there be diuels, would I were a deuill,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: To liue and burne in euerlasting fire,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: So I might haue your company in hell,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: But to torment you with my bitter tongue.

lines.speaker: Luci.
lines.text: Sirs stop his mouth, & let him speake no more.

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: My Lord, there is a Messenger from Rome

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Desires to be admitted to your presence.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Let him come neere.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Welcome {% italic: Emillius %}, what the newes from Rome?

lines.speaker: Emi.
lines.text: Lord {% italic: Lucius %}, and you Princes of the Gothes,

lines.speaker: Emi.
lines.text: The Romaine Emperour greetes you all by me,

lines.speaker: Emi.
lines.text: And for he vnderstands you are in Armes,

lines.speaker: Emi.
lines.text: He craues a parly at your Fathers house

lines.speaker: Emi.
lines.text: Willing you to demand your Hostages,

lines.speaker: Emi.
lines.text: And they shall be immediately deliuered.

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: What saies our Generall?

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: {% italic: Emillius %}, let the Emperour giue his pledges

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Vnto my Father, and my Vncle {% italic: Marcus %},

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: And we will come: march away.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Thus in this strange and sad Habilliament,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: I will encounter with {% italic: Andronicus %},

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: And say, I am Reuenge sent from below,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: To ioyne with him and right his hainous wrongs:

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Knocke at his study where they say he keepes,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: To ruminate strange plots of dire Reuenge,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Tell him Reuenge is come to ioyne with him,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: And worke confusion on his Enemies.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Who doth mollest my Contemplation?

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Is it your tricke to make me ope the dore,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: That so my sad decrees may flie away,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And all my studie be to no effect?

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: You are deceiu'd, for what I meane to do,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: See heere in bloody lines I haue set downe:

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And what is written shall be executed.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: {% italic: Titus %}, I am come to talke with thee,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: No not a word: how can I grace my talke,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Wanting a hand to giue it action,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Thou hast the ods of me, therefore no more.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: If thou did'st know me,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Thou would'st talke with me.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: I am not mad, I know thee well enough,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Witnesse this wretched stump,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Witnesse these crimson lines,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Witnesse these Trenches made by griefe and care,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Witnesse the tyring day, and heauie night,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Witnesse all sorrow, that I know thee well

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: For our proud Empresse, Mighty {% italic: Tamora %}:

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Is not thy comming for my other hand?

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Know thou sad man, I am not {% italic: Tamora %},

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: She is thy Enemie, and I thy Friend,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: I am Reuenge sent from th' infernall Kingdome,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: To ease the gnawing Vulture of the mind,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: By working wreakefull vengeance on my Foes:

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Come downe and welcome me to this worlds light,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Conferre with me of Murder and of Death,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Ther's not a hollow Caue or lurking place,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: No Vast obscurity, or Misty vale,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Where bloody Murther or detested Rape,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Can couch for feare, but I will finde them out,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: And in their eares tell them my dreadfull name,

lines.speaker: Tamo.
lines.text: Reuenge, which makes the foule offenders quake.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Art thou Reuenge? and art thou sent to me,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: To be a torment to mine Enemies?

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: I am, therefore come downe and welcome me.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Doe me some seruice ere I come to thee:

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Loe by thy side where Rape and Murder stands,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Now giue some surance that thou art Reuenge,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Stab them, or teare them on thy Chariot wheeles,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And then Ile come and be thy Waggoner,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And whirle along with thee about the Globes.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Prouide thee two proper Palfries, as blacke as Iet,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: To hale thy vengefull Waggon swift away,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And finde out Murder in their guilty cares.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And when thy Car is loaden with their heads,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: I will dismount, and by the Waggon wheele,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Trot like a Seruile footeman all day long,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Euen from {% italic: Eptons %} rising in the East,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Vntill his very downefall in the Sea.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And day by day Ile do this heauy taske,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: So thou destroy Rapine and Murder there.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: These are my Ministers, and come with me.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Are them thy Ministers, what are they call'd?

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Rape and Murder, therefore called so,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Cause they take vengeance of such kind of men.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Good Lord how like the Empresse Sons they are,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And you the Empresse: But we worldly men,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Haue miserable mad mistaking eyes:

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Oh sweet Reuenge, now do I come to thee,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And if one armes imbracement will content thee,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: I will imbrace thee in it by and by.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: This closing with him, fits his Lunacie,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: What ere I forge to feede his braine‑sicke fits,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Do you vphold, and maintaine in your speeches,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: For now he firmely takes me for Reuenge,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: And being Credulous in this mad thought,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Ile make him send for {% italic: Lucius %} his Sonne,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: And whil'st I at a Banquet hold him sure,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Ile find some cunning practise out of hand

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: To scatter and disperse the giddie Gothes,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Or at the least make them his Enemies:

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: See heere he comes, and I must play my theame.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Long haue I bene forlorne, and all for thee,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Welcome dread Fury to my woefull house,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Rapine and Murther, you are welcome too,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: How like the Empresse and her Sonnes you are.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Well are you fitted, had you but a Moore,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Could not all hell afford you such a deuill?

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: For well I wote the Empresse neuer wags;

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: But in her company there is a Moore,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And would you represent our Queene aright

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: It were conuenient you had such a deuill:

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: But welcome as you are, what shall we doe?

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: What would'st thou haue vs doe {% italic: Andronicus %}?

lines.speaker: Dem.
lines.text: Shew me a Murtherer, Ile deale with him.

lines.speaker: Chi.
lines.text: Shew me a Villaine that hath done a Rape,

lines.speaker: Chi.
lines.text: And I am sent to be reueng'd on him.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Shew me a thousand that haue done thee wrong,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: And Ile be reuenged on them all.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Looke round about the wicked streets of Rome,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And when thou find'st a man that's like thy selfe,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Good Murder stab him, hee's a Murtherer.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Goe thou with him, and when it is thy hap

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: To finde another that is like to thee,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Good Rapine stab him, he is a Rauisher.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Go thou with them, and in the Emperours Court,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: There is a Queene attended by a Moore,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Well maist thou know her by thy owne proportion,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: For vp and downe she doth resemble thee.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: I pray thee doe on them some violent death,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: They haue bene violent to me and mine.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Well hast thou lesson'd vs, this shall we do.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: But would it please thee good {% italic: Andronicus %},

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: To send for {% italic: Lucius %} thy thrice Valiant Sonne,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Who leades towards Rome a Band of Warlike Gothes,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: And bid him come and Banquet at thy house.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: When he is heere, euen at thy Solemne Feast,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: I will bring in the Empresse and her Sonnes,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: The Emperour himselfe, and all thy Foes,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: And at thy mercy shall they stoop, and kneele,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: And on them shalt thou ease, thy angry heart:

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: What saies {% italic: Andronicus %} to this deuise?

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: {% italic: Marcus %} my Brother, 'tis sad {% italic: Titus %} calls,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Go gentle {% italic: Marcus %} to thy Nephew {% italic: Lucius %},

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Thou shalt enquire him out among the Gothes,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Bid him repaire to me, and bring with him

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Some of the chiefest Princes of the Gothes,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Bid him encampe his Souldiers where they are,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Tell him the Emperour, and the Empresse too,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Feasts at my house, and he shall Feast with them,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: This do thou for my loue, and so let him,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: As he regards his aged Fathers life.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: This will I do, and soone returne againe.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Now will I hence about thy businesse,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: And take my Ministers along with me.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Nay, nay, let Rape and Murder stay with me,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Or els Ile call my Brother backe againe,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And cleaue to no reuenge but {% italic: Lucius %}.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: What say you Boyes, will you bide with him,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Whiles I goe tell my Lord the Emperour,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: How I haue gouern'd our determined iest?

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Yeeld to his Humour, smooth and speake him faire,

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: And tarry with him till I turne againe.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: I know them all, though they suppose me mad,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And will ore‑reach them in their owne deuises,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: A payre of cursed hell‑hounds and their Dam.

lines.speaker: Dem.
lines.text: Madam depart at pleasure, leaue vs heere.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Farewell {% italic: Andronicus %}, reuenge now goes

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: To lay a complot to betray thy Foes.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: I know thou doo'st, and sweet reuenge farewell.

lines.speaker: Chi.
lines.text: Tell vs old man, how shall we be imploy'd?

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Tut, I haue worke enough for you to doe,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: {% italic: Publius %} come hither, {% italic: Caius, %} and {% italic: Valentine %}.

lines.speaker: Pub.
lines.text: What is your will?

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Know you these two?

lines.speaker: Pub.
lines.text: The Empresse Sonnes

lines.speaker: Pub.
lines.text: I take them, {% italic: Chiron, Demetrius %}.

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: Fie {% italic: Publius, %} fie, thou art too much deceau'd,

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: The one is Murder, Rape is the others name,

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: And therefore bind them gentle {% italic: Publius %},

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: {% italic: Caius %}, and {% italic: Valentine %}, lay hands on them,

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: Oft haue you heard me wish for such an houre,

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: And now I find it, therefore binde them sure,

lines.speaker: Chi.
lines.text: Villaines forbeare, we are the Empresse Sonnes.

lines.speaker: Pub.
lines.text: And therefore do we, what we are commanded.

lines.speaker: Pub.
lines.text: Stop close their mouthes, let them not speake a word,

lines.speaker: Pub.
lines.text: Is he sure bound, looke that you binde them fast.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Come, come {% italic: Lauinia %}, looke, thy Foes are bound,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Sirs stop their mouthes, let them not speake to me,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: But let them heare what fearefull words I vtter.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Oh Villaines, {% italic: Chiron %}, and {% italic: Demetrius %},

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Here stands the spring whom you haue stain'd with mud,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: This goodly Sommer with your Winter mixt,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: You kil'd her husband, and for that vil'd fault,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Two of her Brothers were condemn'd to death,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: My hand cut off, and made a merry iest,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Both her sweet Hands, her Tongue, and that more deere

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Then Hands or tongue, her spotlesse Chastity,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Inhumaine Traytors, you constrain'd and for'st.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: What would you say, if I should let you speake?

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Villaines for shame you could not beg for grace.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Harke Wretches, how I meane to martyr you,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: This one Hand yet is left, to cut your throats,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Whil'st that {% italic: Lauinia %} tweene her stumps doth hold:

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: The Bason that receiues your guilty blood.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: You know your Mother meanes to feast with me,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And calls herselfe Reuenge, and thinkes me mad.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Harke Villaines, I will grin'd your bones to dust,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And with your blood and it, Ile make a Paste,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And of the Paste a Coffen I will reare,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And make two Pasties of your shamefull Heads,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And bid that strumpet your vnhallowed Dam,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Like to the earth swallow her increase.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: This is the Feast, that I haue bid her to,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And this the Banquet she shall surfet on,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: For worse then {% italic: Philomel %} you vsd my Daughter,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And worse then {% italic: Progne %}, I will be reueng'd,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And now prepare your throats: {% italic: Lauinia %} come.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Receiue the blood, and when that they are dead,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Let me goe grin'd their Bones to powder small,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And with this hatefull Liquor temper it,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And in that Paste let their vil'd Heads be bakte,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Come, come, be euery one officious,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: To make this Banket, which I wish might proue,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: More sterne and bloody then the Centaures Feast.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: So now bring them in, for Ile play the Cooke,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And see them ready, gainst their Mother comes.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Vnckle {% italic: Marcus %}, since 'tis my Fathers minde

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: That I repair to Rome, I am content.

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: And ours with thine befall, what Fortune will.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Good Vnckle take you in this barbarous {% italic: Moore %},

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: This Rauenous Tiger, this accursed deuill,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Let him receiue no sustenance, fetter him,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Till he be brought vnto the Emperours face,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: For testimony of her foule proceedings.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: And see the Ambush of our Friends be strong,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: If ere the Emperour meanes no good to vs.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Some deuill whisper curses in my eare,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: And prompt me that my tongue may vtter forth,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: The Venemous Mallice of my swelling heart.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Away Inhumaine Dogge, Vnhallowed Slaue,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Sirs, helpe our Vnckle, to conuey him in,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: The Trumpets shew the Emperour is at hand.

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: What, hath the Firemament more Suns then one?

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: What bootes it thee to call thy selfe a Sunne?

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Romes Emperour & Nephewe breake the parle

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: These quarrels must be quietly debated,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: The Feast is ready which the carefull {% italic: Titus %},

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Hath ordained to an Honourable end,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: For Peace, for Loue, for League, and good to Rome:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Please you therfore draw nie and take your places.

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: {% italic: Marcus %} we will.

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: Welcome my gracious Lord,

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: Welcome Dread Queene,

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: Welcome ye Warlike Gothes, welcome {% italic: Lucius %},

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: And welcome all: although the cheere be poore,

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: 'Twill fill your stomacks, please you eat of it.

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: Why art thou thus attir'd {% italic: Andronicus %}?

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Because I would be sure to haue all well,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: To entertaine your Highnesse, and your Empresse.

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: We are beholding to you good {% italic: Andronicus %}?

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And if your Highnesse knew my heart, you were:

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: My Lord the Emperour resolue me this,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Was it well done of rash {% italic: Virginius %},

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: To slay his daughter with his owne right hand.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Because she was enfor'st, stain'd, and deflowr'd?

lines.speaker: Satur.
lines.text: It was {% italic: Andronicus %}.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Your reason, Mighty Lord?

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: Because the Girle, should not surui ue her shame,

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: And by her presence still renew his sorrowes.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: A reason mighty, strong, and effectuall,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: A patterne, president, and liuely warrant,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: For me (most wretched) to performe the like:

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Die, die, {% italic: Lauinia %}, and thy shame with thee,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And with thy shame, thy Fathers sorrow die.

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: What hast done, vnnaturall and vnkinde?

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Kil'd her for whom my teares haue made me blind.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: I am as wofull as {% italic: Virginius %} was,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And haue a thousand times more cause then he.

lines.speaker: Sat.
lines.text: What was she rauisht? tell who did the deed,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Wilt please you eat,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Wilt please your Highnesse feed?

lines.speaker: Tam.
lines.text: Why hast thou slaine thine onely Daughter?

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: Not I, 'twas {% italic: Chiron %} and {% italic: Demetrius %},

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: They rauisht her, and cut away her tongue,

lines.speaker: Titus.
lines.text: And they, 'twas they, that did her all this wrong.

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Go fetch them hither to vs presently.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Why there they are both, baked in that Pie,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Whereof their Mother daintily hath fed,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Eating the flesh that she herselfe hath bred.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: 'Tis true, 'tis true, witnesse my kniues sharpe point.

lines.speaker: Satu.
lines.text: Die franticke wretch, for this accursed deed.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Can the Sonnes eye, behold his Father bleed?

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: There's meede for meede, death for a deadly deed.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: You sad fac'd men, people and Sonnes of Rome,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: By vprores seuer'd like a flight of Fowle,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Scattred by windes and high tempestuous gusts:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Oh let me teach you how, to knit againe

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: This scattred Corne, into one mutuall sheafe,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: These broken limbs againe into one body.

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Let Rome herselfe be bane vnto herselfe,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: And shee whom mightie kingdomes cursie too,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Like a forlorne and desperate castaway,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Doe shamefull execution on her selfe.

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: But if my frostie signes and chaps of age,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Graue witnesses of true experience,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Cannot induce you to attend my words,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Speake Romes deere friend, as 'erst our Auncestor,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: When with his solemne tongue he did discourse

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: To loue‑sicke {% italic: Didoes %} sad attending eare,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: The story of that balefull burning night,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: When subtil Greekes surpriz'd King {% italic: Priams %} Troy:

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Tell vs what {% italic: Sinon %} hath bewicht our eares,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Or who hath brought the fatall engine in,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: That giues our Troy, our Rome the ciuill wound.

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: My heart is not compact of flint nor steele,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Nor can I vtter all our bitter griefe,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: But floods of teares will drowne my Oratorie,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: And breake my very vttrance, euen in the time

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: When it should moue you to attend me most,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Lending your kind hand Commiseration.

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Heere is a Captaine, let him tell the tale,

lines.speaker: Goth.
lines.text: Your hearts will throb and weepe to heare him speake.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: This Noble Auditory, be it knowne to you,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: That cursed {% italic: Chiron %} and {% italic: Demetrius %}

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Were they that murdred our Emperours Brother,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: And they it were that rauished our Sister,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: For their fell faults our Brothers were beheaded,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Our Fathers teares despis'd, and basely cousen'd,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Of that true hand that fought Romes quarrell out,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: And sent her enemies vnto the graue.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Lastly, my selfe vnkindly banished,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: The gates shut on me, and turn'd weeping out,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: To beg reliefe among Romes Enemies,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Who drown'd their enmity in my true teares,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: And op'd their armes to imbrace me as a Friend:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: And I am turned forth, be it knowne to you,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: That haue preseru'd her welfare in my blood,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: And from her bosome tooke the Enemies point,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Sheathing the steele in my aduentrous body.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Alas you know, I am no Vaunter I,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: My scars can witnesse, dumbe although they are,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: That my report is iust and full of truth:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: But soft, me thinkes I do digresse too much,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Cyting my worthlesse praise: Oh pardon me,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: For when no Friends are by, men praise themselues,

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: Now is my turne to speake: Behold this Child,

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: Of this was {% italic: Tamora %} deliuered,

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: The issue of an Irreligious {% italic: Moore %},

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: Chiefe Architect and plotter of these woes,

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: The Villaine is aliue in {% italic: Titus %} house,

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: And as he is, to witnesse this is true.

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: Now iudge what course had {% italic: Titus %} to reuenge

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: These wrongs, vnspeakeable past patience,

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: Or more then any liuing man could beare.

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: Now you haue heard the truth, what say you Romaines?

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: Haue we done ought amisse? shew vs wherein,

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: And from the place where you behold vs now,

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: The poore remainder of {% italic: Andronici %},

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: Will hand in hand all headlong cast vs downe,

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: And on the ragged stones beat forth our braines,

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: And make a mutuall closure of our house:

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: Speake Romaines speake, and if you say we shall,

lines.speaker: Marc.
lines.text: Loe hand in hand, {% italic: Lucius %} and I will fall.

lines.speaker: Emilli.
lines.text: Come come, thou reuerent man of Rome,

lines.speaker: Emilli.
lines.text: And bring our Emperour gently in thy hand,

lines.speaker: Emilli.
lines.text: {% italic: Lucius %} our Emperour: for well I know,

lines.speaker: Emilli.
lines.text: The common voyce do cry it shall be so.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: {% italic: Lucius %}, all haile Romes Royall Emperour,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Goe, goe into old {% italic: Titus %} sorrowfull house,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And hither hale that misbelieuing {% italic: Moore %},

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: To be adiudg'd some direfull slaughtering death,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: As punishment for his most wicked life.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: {% italic: Lucius %} all haile to Romes gracious Gouernour.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Thankes gentle Romanes, may I gouerne so,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: To heale Romes harmes, and wipe away her woe.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: But gentle people, giue me ayme a‑while,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: For Nature puts me to a heauy taske:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Stand all aloofe, but Vnckle draw you neere,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: To shed obsequious teares vpon this Trunke:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Oh take this warme kisse on thy pale cold lips,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: These sorrowfull drops vpon thy bloud‑slaine face,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: The last true Duties of thy Noble Sonne.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Teare for teare, and louing kisse for kisse,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Thy Brother {% italic: Marcus %} tenders on thy Lips:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: O were the summe of these that I should pay

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Countlesse, and infinit, yet would I pay them.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Come hither Boy, come, come, and learne of vs

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: To melt in showres: thy Grandsire lou'd thee well:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Many a time he danc'd thee on his knee:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Sung thee asleepe, his Louing Brest, thy Pillow:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Many a matter hath he told to thee,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Meete, and agreeing with thine Infancie:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: In that respect then, like a louing Childe,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Shed yet some small drops from thy tender Spring,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Because kinde Nature doth require it so:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Friends, should associate Friends, in Greefe and Wo.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Bid him farwell, commit him to the Graue,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Do him that kindnesse, and take leaue of him.

lines.speaker: Boy.
lines.text: O Grandsire, Grandsire: euen with all my heart

lines.speaker: Boy.
lines.text: Would I were Dead, so you did Liue againe.

lines.speaker: Boy.
lines.text: O Lord, I cannot speake to him for weeping,

lines.speaker: Boy.
lines.text: My teares will choake me, if I ope my mouth.

lines.speaker: Romans.
lines.text: You sad {% italic: Andronici %}, haue done with woes,

lines.speaker: Romans.
lines.text: Giue sentence on this execrable Wretch,

lines.speaker: Romans.
lines.text: That hath beene breeder of these dire euents.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Set him brest deepe in earth, and famish him:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: There let him stand, and raue, and cry for foode:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: If any one releeues, or pitties him,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: For the offence, he dyes. This is our doome:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Some stay, to see him fast'ned in the earth.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: O why should wrath be mute, & Fury dumbe?

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: I am no Baby I, that with base Prayers

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: I should repent the Euils I haue done.

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Ten thousand worse, then euer yet I did,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: Would I performe if I might haue my will:

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: If one good Deed in all my life I did,

lines.speaker: Aron.
lines.text: I do repent it from my very Soule.

lines.speaker: Lucius.
lines.text: Some louing Friends conuey the hence,

lines.speaker: Lucius.
lines.text: And giue him buriall in his Fathers graue.

lines.speaker: Lucius.
lines.text: My Father, and {% italic: Lauinia %}, shall forthwith

lines.speaker: Lucius.
lines.text: Be closed in our Housholds Monument:

lines.speaker: Lucius.
lines.text: As for that heynous Tyger {% italic: Tamora %},

lines.speaker: Lucius.
lines.text: No Funerall Rite, nor man in mournfull Weeds: A partially inked spacing block appears at the end of this line.

lines.speaker: Lucius.
lines.text: No mournfull Bell shall ring her Buriall:

lines.speaker: Lucius.
lines.text: But throw her foorth to Beasts and Birds of prey:

lines.speaker: Lucius.
lines.text: Her life was Beast‑like, and deuoid of pitty,

lines.speaker: Lucius.
lines.text: And being so, shall haue like want of pitty.

lines.speaker: Lucius.
lines.text: See Iustice done on {% italic: Aaron %} that damn'd Moore,

lines.speaker: Lucius.
lines.text: From whom, our heauy happes had their beginning:

lines.speaker: Lucius.
lines.text: Then afterwards, to Order well the State,

lines.speaker: Lucius.
lines.text: That like Euents, may ne're it Ruinate.
